Constructing User Interfaces

Why are we coding?

All design artifacts go through a translation when they move from paper or pixels to code.

As a designer you want to play an active role in that translation.

You aren't expected to come out of this with a deep coding profiency.

But you will have an understanding of how web interfaces are constructed and that will make you a better designer.

Why web interfaces?

Web UIs are still some of the most complex to build.

Web technologies are still ubiquitous.

This week we'll focus on html & css. In the coming weeks we'll incorporate javascript.

HTML

Gives a document structure.

CSS

Gives a document style.

Javascript

Gives a document behaviors & interaction.

HTML

Here's all the HTML you need to know to get started.

HTML is comprised of tags.

<p>
This is a paragraph tag. 
Tags give content meaning and structure. 
</p>

Tags can nest inside other tags. HTML documents are trees of nested tags.

Here's an unordered list with nested list items

<ul>
  <li>list item</li>
  <li>list item</li>
  <li>list item</li>
</ul>

Some tags are self closing.

br (line break) is an example.

<br/>

Tags can have attributes.

The image tag (img) has a source attribute (src) that points to a file.

<img src="logo.png"/>


class is how we target a tag for styling with css.

<p class="lead">Lead paragraph</p>


id gives an element a unique value. It's helpful for targeting an item with javascript.

<button id='product-1234'>Add to cart</button>

This is what the first website looked like.

HTML tags are what give pages on the internet a common structure.

Without it there wouldn't be any of the interoperability that makes searching and linking possible.

The # of html tags is limited when you consider the amount of variation on the internet.

You won't find a tag for every structural element or UI component.

Most tags don't have any specific visual traits associated with them. They exist to wrap your content and give it meaningful structure.

The visual appearance of the page is where the next technology, CSS, comes into play

CSS

CSS adds color, typography, page composition and animation to the web.

The web would be a sad place without it.

CSS works by selecting elements on the page and applying styles to them.

This is a css ruleset. Can you describe what it does?


p{
  font-size: 32px;
  color: red;
}
